@dabeaz that is‚Ä¶ frightening. If not entirely global, a stack of contexts where closest wins is the typical way that these things work.
@dabeaz the model where outermost wins is basically incoherent‚Ä¶ most precedence but least information about what's happening?
@dabeaz the size shouldn't be relevant, there are local reasons to move the timeout in either direction, might be known to be expensive
@dabeaz benefit of having only the function variant is that you are not dependent on any sort of threadlocal or module scoped variables
@dabeaz I'd expect that the innermost (most specific) applies, in this case 5. Can also disambiguate nested with timeout blocks that way.

@timburks @alexisgallagher @bitemyapp @pelotom Yep. If you control both ends, serialized binary w/ extensible schema is king.
@reebalazs yeah, 140 character limit :) If you have webpack around that more or less implies that you can install whatever.
@pelotom @bitemyapp @alexisgallagher YAML parsing ain't easy. At least two orders of magnitude harder than JSON.
@pelotom @bitemyapp @alexisgallagher the complexity created a huge attack surface too (mostly DoS style stuff)
@pelotom yes, but it's hard to get rid of all those things and when we burned it down for JSON we got other benefits along the way
@pelotom it's the associated complexity (schemas, namespaces, xpath, etc.), bad use cases (SOAP, config files), and worse APIs
@pelotom because JSX looks like HTML if you squint, and it's not just recklessly smashing strings together like most template things.

@IanMLewis @jdunck @haxor @ncoghlan_dev which I have done, but pip install gets that wrong if requirements.txt isn't topologically sorted
@jdunck @haxor @ncoghlan_dev req says B==1, pip installs latest anyway because that constraint comes later in requirements.txt
@IanMLewis @jdunck @haxor @ncoghlan_dev B==1.0 isn't installed until after A==1.0 fails to install with the latest version of B
@amfarrell @__mharrison__ Conda looks like a real solution to this problem, will look into switching. Thanks!
@jdunck @haxor @ncoghlan_dev sure, but changing third party packages is the wrong solution to the fact that pip ignores requirements.
@rbtcollins nothing was skipped when I found the bug, it was pip freeze output
@ncoghlan_dev @haxor surely some information is already stored at install time in order to keep the distribution names and versions.
@ncoghlan_dev @haxor topological freeze is possible by recording dependencies at install time. Can still be pathologically dynamic.
@2xlp the lines of requirements.txt just needs to be in the correct order (not pip freeze's alphabetical order). No scripts needed.
@haxor @ncoghlan_dev not the problem. Req.txt says "A==1.0 B==1.0", A depends on B and fails to build against B 2.0 because pip is not smart
@2xlp loading is the most broken, but creating doesn't cope with the naive loading implementation
@haxor @ncoghlan_dev the "everything is terrible" workaround is to re-order requirements.txt by hand in a topological not alphabetical order
@haxor @ncoghlan_dev the best solution would be to fix pip install to consider all the constraints rather than just running through in-order
@sayrer sadly I don't have the resources to rewrite all of the things and teach everyone else Go (or any language other than Python).
TIL the order of dependencies in a requirements.txt is meaningful, so pip freeze isn't as reproducible as you might think #python #pip #sigh
